1. FACILITY POLICY
     
THE MANAGEMENT AND EMPLOYEES OF THE OTTAWA COOPEATIVE ASSOCIATION ARE COMMITTED TO THE PREVENTION OF ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA. IF AN ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SHOULD OCCUR, THE FACILITY IS PREPARED TO WORK WITH THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT AND OR OTHER AUTHORITIES, TO MITIGATE AND MINIMIZE THE IMPACTS OF THE RELEASE TO THE PEOPLE AND THE ENVIRONMENT. 

     2. FACILITY INFORMATION
     
OUR PLANT CONSIST OF TWO NH3 STORAGE VESSELS AND ELEVEN NURSE TANKS.  OUR MAXIMUM INVENTORY REPORT IS ON FILE IN THE RMP COMPLIANCE MANUAL AND HAS ALSO BEEN SHARED WITH THE LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONDERS FOR PRE-PLANNING EXERCISES.

     3. WORST CASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO

 THE WORST CASE AND THE ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIOS HAVE BEEN EVALUATED AND SHARED WITH OUR LOCAL FIRST RESPONDERS AS PART OF AN ON-GOING TRAINING PROGRAM.  MORE IMPORTANTLY, OUR EMPLOYEES HAVE BEEN TRAINED IN THEIR RESPECTIVE EMERGENCY ACTIONS, INCLUDING THE EMERGENCY MEETING PLACE AND EACH OF THEIR INDIVIDUAL RESPONSIBILITIES REGARDING AN ACCIDENTAL RELEASE OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA.     

     4. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PROGRAM
     
THE FACILITY IS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE PROVISIONS OF THE U.S. OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH ADMINISTRATION (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "STORAGE AND HANDLING OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA". THIS FACILITY IS ALSO IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE PROVISIONS OF THE KANSAS FERTILIZER LAW. THE OSHA STANDARD IS REFERENCED IN THE RMP REGISTRATION FORM IN SECTION 8.3 (b).
      THERE ARE MANY HAZARDS ASSOCIATED  WITH ANHYDROUS AMMONIA. WE REQUIRE THAT EACH EMPLOYEE THAT LOADS AMMONIA BE TRAINED EVERY THREE YEARS AT A STATE SPONSERED TRAINING SCHOOL AND YEARLY TRAINED IN OPERATING AND SAFETY PRODEDURES AT A GIVEN AMMONIA PLANT. ALL EMPLOYEES ARE TRAINED TO INSPECT THE AMMONIA PLANT BEFORE FILLING PROCEDURES AND BEFORE USE  DO A VISUAL INSPECTION OF ALL HOSES AND VALVES TO MAKE SURE THERE HAS NOT BEEN A FAILURE OF EQUIPMENT SINCE THE LAST TIME IT WAS USED. EMPLOYEES ARE REM

INDED TO FOLLOW START UP PROCEDURES BEFORE FILLING AND DURING FILLING OF  NURSE TANKS.

     5. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
     
THERE HAVE BEEN NO ACCIDENTAL RELEASES OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA IN THE PAST FIVE YEARS THAT HAVE CAUSED ANY DEATHS, INJURIES OR SIGNIFICANT PROPERY DAMAGE AT THE FACILITY, NOR TO OUR KNOWLEDGE, HAS THERE BEEN ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASES RESULTING IN OFF SITE DEATHS, INJURIES, EVACUATIONS, PROPERTY DAMAGE, OR ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE. 

      6. EMERGENCY ACTION  PLAN
      
      A. A WRITTEN ACTION PLAN, IN ACCORDANCE WITH OSHA STANDARD 29 CFR 1910-38

      B. PROVIDED STATE AND LOCAL AUTHORITIES WITH THE EMERGENCY PLANNING AND COMMUNITY RIGHT TO KNOW INFORMATION AS REQUIRED UNDER SARA TITLE III (EPCRA).

      C. IF A LARGE RELEASE OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA TAKES PLACE AT THE FACILITY, THE REQUIRED RESPONSE ACTION IS TO EVACUATE THE AREA OF THE SPILL AND CALL 911 AND ALL APPLICABLE EMERGENCY RESPONSE NUMBERS.
       1. WITHIN 15 MINUTES OF DETERMINING THE AMOUNT OF RELEASE WOULD BE OVER 100 POUNDS, THE EMERGENCY COORDINATOR WILL NOTIFY: THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER (800-424-8802).
       2. WITHIN 24 HOURS OF DETERMINING THE AMOUNT OF RELEASE WOULD EFFECT THE ENVIRONMENT THE EMERGENCY COORDINATOR WILL NOTIFY: KANSAS BUREAU OF ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION (785-296-1679) OR AFTER NORMAL BUSINESS HOURS (785-296-0614) AND THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT (785-296-3176) AND IN ALL RELEASES  THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE (785-296-3301).

      7. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
      
SAFETY IMPROVEMENT IS AN ONGOING PROCESS AT THE FACILITY. PERODIC EVALUATIONS ARE PERFORMED TO ASSESS THE CONDITIONS OF THE FACILITY. THERE ARE NO ADDITIONAL SPECIFIC SAFETY RECOMMENDATIONS REGARDING STORAGE OR USE OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA FOR IMPLEMENTATION AT THIS TIME.
